content:
Soon-to be masters student of bioinformatics at the University of Maryland University College. Research interests include: transcriptomic profiling of memory-like NK cells, transcriptomic modulation during viral infection, and automated analyses of flow cytometry data.
Outside of the lab I enjoy competitive strength sports, hiking, and cycling around the Fells.
summary:
Soon-to be masters student of bioinformatics at the University of Maryland University College. Research interests include: transcriptomic profiling of memory-like NK cells, transcriptomic modulation during viral infection, and automated analyses of flow cytometry data.
Outside of the lab I enjoy competitive strength sports, hiking, and cycling around the Fells.
title: Kyle Kroll

content: My lab’s research has provided comprehensive characterizations of NK cells in nonhuman primate species and revealed significant heterogeneity among NK cells in tissues outside peripheral blood, including identification of previously unknown subpopulations of NK cells in tissues. Notably, we were the first to characterize IL-17/IL-22-producing NKp44+ mucosa-restricted NK cells in macaque species, and were the first to delineate mechanisms of depletion of these cells during lentivirus infections. We have also recently presented the first evidence of NK cell memory in any primate species.
summary: My lab’s research has provided comprehensive characterizations of NK cells in nonhuman primate species and revealed significant heterogeneity among NK cells in tissues outside peripheral blood, including identification of previously unknown subpopulations of NK cells in tissues. Notably, we were the first to characterize IL-17/IL-22-producing NKp44+ mucosa-restricted NK cells in macaque species, and were the first to delineate mechanisms of depletion of these cells during lentivirus infections. We have also recently presented the first evidence of NK cell memory in any primate species.
title: Keith Reeves

content: My lab is currently addressing whether human NK cells are endowed with antigenic specificity and immunological memory to viruses, and how interactions between NK cells and other immune cells modulate the development of virus-specific adaptive immune responses. The primary goal of those studies is to provide the rationale to develop novel approaches aiming at harnessing NK cell function to enhance the efficacy of future vaccines.
summary: My lab is currently addressing whether human NK cells are endowed with antigenic specificity and immunological memory to viruses, and how interactions between NK cells and other immune cells modulate the development of virus-specific adaptive immune responses. The primary goal of those studies is to provide the rationale to develop novel approaches aiming at harnessing NK cell function to enhance the efficacy of future vaccines.
title: Stephanie Jost

content: Using cutting edge technologies in flow cytometry, RNA sequencing, and -omics tools we are trying to break down and map the fundamental mechanisms behind HIV/SIV resevoir clearance by NK cells and antigen-specific NK cell memory.
summary: Using cutting edge technologies in flow cytometry, RNA sequencing, and -omics tools we are trying to break down and map the fundamental mechanisms behind HIV/SIV resevoir clearance by NK cells and antigen-specific NK cell memory.
title: Reeves & Jost Lab

summary: Dimensionality Reduction and Visualization for Flow Cytometry
title: CytoDRAV

content:
One of the projects here at the Reeves Lab involves cloning NK populations from single NK cells. We utilize two methods for this assay: limiting serial dilutions and sorting. Cells are cultured with feeder cells, irradiated autologous PBMCs and IL-2. After ~4-6 weeks the cell cultures have grown enough in size to phenotypically and functionally characterize.
One interesting result we have seen is that some clonal populations from PLWH is that they respond in a greater magnitude to Env or Gag presenting autologous BLCLs. We are using multiple approaches to try and determine what transcriptomic or proteomic changes are occuring that infer memory like responses to these clones.
summary: Attempting to find a transcriptomic signature of single-cell NK clones that respond in a memory-like fasion to HIV antigens.
title: Transcriptomic Signatures of HIV-specific NK Clones

content:
Hello and welcome to the new home for the Reeves Lab!
The goal here is to highlight the work that we here are doing so that we can reach a broad audience with our research into natural killer cells and HIV/SIV!
summary:

title: Welcome

summary: Here we show that we can identify specific NK cell subpopulations that are modulated following chronic, but not acute, SIV infection.
title: SIV infection modulates CD94 (KLRD1)+ NK cells in rhesus macaques.

summary: In this review, we will describe multiple aspects of NK cell biology in HIV/SIV infections and their association with viral control and disease progression, and how NHP models were critical in detailing each finding.
title: Monkeying Around: Using Non-human Primate Models to Study NK Cell Biology in HIV Infections

summary: Here we show that we can identify specific NK cell subpopulations that are modulated following chronic, but not acute, SIV infection.
title: Semaphorin 7A modulates cytokine-induced memory-like responses by human natural killer cells.

summary: With a broader acceptance of research supporting adaptive functions in NK cells it is likely that novel immunotherapeutics and vaccine modalities will aim to generate virus-specific memory NK cells. In doing so, better targeted NK cell responses against virus-infected cells may usher in a new era of NK cell-tuned immune therapy.
title: Adaptive NK cell responses in HIV/SIV infections: A roadmap to cell-based therapeutics?

summary: We provide a mechanism of virus-dependent alternative signaling that may explain the acquisition of adaptive features by primate NK cells and could be targeted for future vaccine or curative therapies.
title: CMV Primes Functional Alternative Signaling in Adaptive Δg NK Cells but Is Subverted by Lentivirus Infection in Rhesus Macaques

summary: This review will provide a comprehensive outline of the cytokine-mediated exacerbation of disease and tissue damage in NHP models of viral infections and therapeutic strategies that can aid in prevention/treatment of the disease syndromes.
title: Cytokine-Mediated Tissue Injury in Non-human Primate Models of Viral Infections.

summary: Herein, we demonstrate functional NK cell responses to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) of potential oral pathogens in rhesus macaques.
title: Indirect activation of rhesus macaque (Macaca mulatta) NK cells in oral and mucosal draining lymph nodes.

summary: The objective of this study was to identify NKB cells in primates and study the impact of HIV/SIV infections.
title: Progressive lentivirus infection induces natural killer cell receptor-expressing B cells in the gastrointestinal tract

summary: Using novel RNA-based flow cytometry, we identify for the first time true memory NKG2C+ NK cells in NHP by gene expression (KLRC2), and show that these cells have elevated frequencies and diversify their functional repertoire specifically in response to rhCMV and SIV infections.
title: Tracking KLRC2 (NKG2C)+ memory-like NK cells in SIV+ and rhCMV+ rhesus macaques.

summary: In this review, we will describe multiple aspects of NK cell biology in HIV/SIV infections and their association with viral control and disease progression, and how NHP models were critical in detailing each finding.
title: Innate Lymphoid Cells in HIV/SIV Infections
